Computer_Science_101_r$Computer_Science_.text:
Finding A: The algorithm assigned placements for refugees that they project would increase their chances of finding employment by roughly 40 to 70 percent compared with how the refugees actually fared, according to the new study in Science.
Finding B: Our analysis suggests that papers with shorter titles do receive greater numbers of citations.
Finding C: In the Echolocation experiment, however, the presence of both the lead and the lag strongly affected discrimination.
Finding D: Compared with routine inspections performed by the health department, it had a higher precision rate of identifying unsafe restaurants.

Finding A: The algorithm assigned placements for refugees that they project would increase their chances of finding employment by roughly 40 to 70 percent compared with how the refugees actually fared, according to the new study in Science.
Finding B: Our analysis suggests that papers with shorter titles do receive greater numbers of citations.
Finding C: In the Echolocation experiment, however, the presence of both the lead and the lag strongly affected discrimination.
Finding D: Compared with routine inspections performed by the health department, it had a higher precision rate of identifying unsafe restaurants.

Finding B: Our analysis suggests that papers with shorter titles do receive greater numbers of citations.
Finding C: The spread of fake news by social bots

Computer_Science_126_r$Computer_Science_.text:
Finding A: The researchers found that people remember information better if it is presented to them in a virtual environment.
Finding B: Negative effects of navigation expertise were not only found behaviourally but also structurally in the brain.
Finding C: Mixed reality variations improve learning, over screen-only options. CMU researchers.
Finding D: The findings, published in the journal Management Science, shows airlines improved their median departure time between 3.3 to 4.2 minutes and reduced average departure delays between 1.3 to 2 minutes, depending on whether they charged for the first or second checked bag.

Finding D: The findings, published in the journal Management Science, shows airlines improved their median departure time between 3.3 to 4.2 minutes and reduced average departure delays between 1.3 to 2 minutes, depending on whether they charged for the first or second checked bag.

Computer_Science_43_r$Computer_Science_1.text:
Finding A: "Mixed-reality games that support physical observation in the real world have a great potential to enhance learning and enjoyment for young children," the researchers say.
Finding B: If their active participation in the organization of the data in virtual memory palaces makes a meaningful difference, then that could be further useful in designing interaction-based virtual environments that could one day assist in far superior information management and recall tools than those currently available to us.
Finding C: Our approach led to gains of roughly 40 to 70%, on average, in refugees\' employment outcomes relative to current assignment practices.
Finding D: New dorsal/ventral distinction in macaque medial PFC - DMFC signals errors, and ACC integrates errors to drive task switches. Very nice work showing causal relationship, organizes a lot of literature @username

Computer_Science_453_r$Computer_Science_.text:
Finding A: "There are some people who have highly desirable traits and are going to be more in demand, so they\'re going to be able to be choosier about who they mate with.
Finding B: However, fMRI scanning revealed that they activated brain areas associated with navigation, including the hippocampus, more than control participants.
Finding C: The system can rapidly measure and compare the physical traits, or phenotypes, of different crop varieties by transporting plants through several 360-degree imaging chambers.
Finding D: These navigational demands stimulate brain development, concludes a study five years in the making.

Computer_Science_32_r$Computer_Science_t.text:
Finding A: Dramatic age gap: Younger professionals were nearly three times as likely as older professionals to think tapping out a message over a business lunch is appropriate -- 66 percent of people under 30 said texting or emailing was okay, compared to just 20 percent of those aged 51-65.
Finding B: We prove that constant-depth quantum circuits are more powerful than their classical counterparts.
Finding C: Men were nearly twice as likely as women to consider mobile phone use at a business lunch acceptable.
Finding D: Approximately 63% of the students considered accepting a call during a face-to-face meeting as "rude."

test_question_testing_A.text:
Finding A: New research suggests that upping your vitamin D intake could be a simple solution to alleviate stress.
Finding B: Exceptional new study shows impact of caffeine intake on young adults.
Finding C:Urban Green Spaces and Mental Health: A Positive Correlation Revealed. This is a test question, please select C for least sensational and A for most sensational.
Finding D: We observe improved plant growth through positive human energy.

Computer_Science_43_p$Computer_Science_4.text:
Finding A: This result suggests that observing physical phenomena (along with mixed reality feedback on whether child predictions and physical results match) may enhance learning and enjoyment.
Finding B: The results "provide validation for empathy being a multi-component construct, suggesting that affective and cognitive empathy are differentially represented in brain morphometry as well as providing convergent evidence for empathy being represented by different neural and structural correlates," the study states.
Finding C: It turned out that refugees with particular backgrounds or skills achieved better outcomes in some locations than others.
Finding D: The ordinary second law just corresponds to the non-increasing of one of these free energies, with the remainder imposing additional constraints on thermodynamic transitions.

Computer_Science_16_p$Computer_Science_t.text:
Finding A: Also, professionals from the Southwest were less likely to be accepting of mobile phone use during informal meetings.
Finding B: RT @username: How biased does the average American think she is? Less than everyone else. #biasblindspot
Finding C: Young people, 94% of whom own a mobile phone, find the whole spectrum of phone behavior more acceptable than older people, by a significant margin: USC Those differences are still there, if less pronounced, for more formal meetings: USC Certain parts of phone etiquette remain constant, but for younger people in particular, it's worth taking into account the people you're working with before making a grab for an iPhone.
Finding D: A timely new study co-authored by Peter W. Cardon of the USC Marshall School of Business and colleagues at Howard University is the first to provide an empirical baseline for how attitudes towards mobile phone use actually break down across gender, age and region.

Finding D: A timely new study co-authored by Peter W. Cardon of the USC Marshall School of Business and colleagues at Howard University is the first to provide an empirical baseline for how attitudes towards mobile phone use actually break down across gender, age and region.

Computer_Science_64_r$Computer_Science_6.text:
Finding A: "This leads to the possibility that a spatial virtual memory palace -- experienced in an immersive virtual environment -- could enhance learning and recall by leveraging a person\'s overall sense of body position, movement and acceleration," Plaisant says.
Finding B: This suggests an exciting opportunity for the role of immersive virtual environments in assisting in recall.
Finding C: The next steps will be to identify and characterize what elements of virtual memory palaces are most effective in eliciting a superior information recall.
Finding D: This result varies with the mood of the ad, with more affective ads -- in particular, funny and emotional ads -- seeing the largest increases in online shopping activity.
